0.text: Mehevi and the other chiefs seem slightly angry at Tommo after Marnoo leaves. Even Kory-Kory appears to bear him a small grudge. Tommo now has been in the valley for about two months and his leg feels so well that he moves around easily. One day he makes a small 'pop-gun' out of bamboo for a six-year old boy, which shoots items out when one blows on it. The boy is fascinated. Soon after, groups of men and women appear and beg Tommo to make more. He does so, and they all run around like children playing with the guns. Their excitement continues for almost ten days. Tommo stops wearing the shoes that he brought from the ship and he ties them in his bundle near the roof. One day Marheyo suggests interest in them and Tommo gives them to him. Marheyo starts wearing the shoes on a strap around his chest, as a bizarre necklace. The Typees do not work very frequently, but one task with which most women assist is the making of the cloth, or 'tappa. Tappa making involves boiling branches from trees and stretching fibers. The process is described in full

2.text: Tommo and the other chiefs seemed a little displeased with him after Marnoo left. Even Kory-Kory was a little jealous of him. Tommo had been in the valley for nearly two months and his feet felt very good, he could move easily. One day, he made a small 'gun' out of bamboo for a six-year-old boy, it could shoot objects when someone inhaled. The boy was enchanted. Then, groups of men and women appeared and asked Tommo to make more. He did so, and they all ran around like children playing with a gun. Their excitement continued for nearly ten days. Tommo stopped wearing the shoes he had brought from the ship and tied them into his bag near the top. One day, Marheyo proposed some benefits and Tommo gave them to him. Marheyo began wearing the shoes on a cord around his chest, like a strange bottle. The Typees do not work regularly, but a job that most women help with is producing cloth, or 'tappa'. Producing tappa involves boiling branches from trees and pulling threads. The process is described in detail in the section below.

4.text: Tommo and the other chiefs seemed a bit displeased with him after Marnoo left. Even Kory-Kory seemed a bit jealous of him. One day, he created a small breathing tube made of wood for a six-year-old boy, it could shoot objects when someone breathed into it. The boy was enchanted. Then, groups of men and women appeared and asked Tommo to do more. He did so, and they all ran around like children playing with a breathing tube. Their excitement lasted for nearly ten days. Tommo stopped wearing the boots he had brought from the ship and tied them into a bag. One day, Marheyo proposed some benefits and Tommo agreed to them. Marheyo started wearing the boots on a string around his chest, like a peculiar bottle. The Typees did not work according to rules, but a job that most women helped with was producing cloth, or 'tappa'. Producing tappa involved cooking branches from trees and pulling fibers. This process is described in detail in the section below.

Tommo had stopped wearing the sandals he had worn since boarding the ship and tied them into a bag. One day, Marheyo proposed some benefits, and Tommo agreed to them. Marheyo began to wear the sandals around his waist in a circular shape, like a special pouch. The Typee people did not work according to rules, but one job that most women helped with was producing cloth, or 'tappa'. Producing tappa involved boiling resin from trees and pulling fibers. This process is described in detail below.

0.text: Emma mourns the departure of Leon. Gloom pervades her thoughts over the loss, and romanticism colors her vision, as she makes him into 'a taller, handsomer, a more delightful, and a vaguer Leon. ' With the passage of time, her passion dims, and 'the black days she had known at Tostes  again. ' She becomes unpredictable, given to strange whims. Charles' mother only makes things worse. In the midst of Emma's depression, Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy bachelor and landowner, calls on Charles when one of his servants needs urgent medical treatment. Boulanger sees Emma as she helps her husband and notices her sensuousness. Attracted to Emma, he wonders how to get rid of his present mistress.

2.text: Emma smiled when Leon left. Fog enveloped her thoughts about the loss, and the love of color for her vision, as she turned him into 'Leon taller, more beautiful, happier, and more mysterious.' As time passed, her infatuation gradually faded, and 'the dark days she knew in Tostes again.' She became unpredictable, easily swayed by her unusual desires. Her mother made things worse. When Emma was in a melancholy state, Rodolphe Boulanger, a wealthy, single landowner, visited Charles because one of his employees needed emergency medical treatment. Boulanger saw Emma while she was helping her husband and was drawn to her beauty. He was surprised by Emma, wondering how to get rid of her current lover.

0.text: Jude starts looking for a job in Christminster, and as soon as he is offered one , he accepts it. By night he studies sincerely. He spends his money on books, pens and paper even though he cannot afford a fire. When it is too cold, he sits up reading wrapped in a greatcoat, hat and woolen gloves. He persuades his aunt to send him the portrait of Sue and she does so, but reluctantly, and with a warning not to contact Sue. But Jude learns that Sue is working in an ecclesiastical goods shop and eventually discovers her there one day at work. He does not introduce himself to her. Later, she passes him by on the street. He notices her elegance and sophistication in contrast to his own rustic ways. He still does not speak to her and resolves not to think of her except as a relative.

2.text: Jude started looking for a job in Christminster, and as soon as he had the opportunity, he accepted it. At night, he studied seriously. He spent his money on books, pens, and paper, although he couldn't afford the fire. When the weather was too cold, he sat reading in a large coat, a hat, and a pair of wool gloves. He managed to persuade his aunt to send him Sue's picture, and she did, but reluctantly, and with a warning not to contact Sue. But Jude knew that Sue was working at a church goods shop, and eventually, he found her one day at work. He didn't introduce himself to her. Later, she walked past him on the street. He noticed her refinement and elegance compared to his wild style. He still didn't talk to her and decided not to think about her beyond family terms.

25.text: Jude bắt đầu tìm kiếm việc làm ở Christminster và chấp nhận một công việc càng sớm càng tốt.  Vào tối, anh dành thời gian cho những nghiên cứu nghiêm túc.  Anh sử dụng tiền của mình để mua sách, bút, và giấy, mặc dù anh không thể chi trả cho than.  Khi thời tiết quá lạnh, anh ngồi đọc sách trong một chiếc áo khoác lớn, một chiếc mũ, và một đôi bàn tay vải len.  Anh cố gắng thuyết phục cô dì của mình gửi cho anh một bức ảnh của Sue, và cô đã làm như vậy, mặc dù miễn cưỡng, và với một cảnh báo không nên tham gia với Sue.  Nhưng Jude biết rằng Sue đang làm việc tại cửa hàng đồ nội thất của nhà thờ, và cuối cùng anh đã tìm thấy cô một ngày nào đó khi cô đang làm việc.  Anh không tự giới thiệu mình với cô.  Sau đó cô đi qua anh.  Anh nhận thấy sự tinh tế và phong cách của cô, trong khi phong cách của anh vẫn còn thô ráp.  Anh chưa bao giờ nói chuyện với cô và quyết định không nghĩ về cô, ngoại trừ trong bối cảnh gia đình.

0.text: After the combats of the first day at Ashby, the crowds eagerly await the events of the next day. The excitement reaches a fever pitch when the Disinherited Knight is attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert. With the help of another mysterious character, the Black Knight, who comes to his aid, Ivanhoe overcomes his challengers, emerging the victor once again. After the victory, the Black Knight disappears. Rowena crowns the Disinherited Knight, who is now forced to raise his visor and show his face. He is revealed to all as Ivanhoe, Cedrics son. Severely wounded, he faints at Rowenas feet.

2.text: After the battles that took place on the first day at Ashby, the crowd eagerly awaited the events of the next day. Emotions reached a peak when the Black Knight was attacked simultaneously by Athelstane, Front-de-Boeuf, and Bois-Guilbert. With the help of another enigmatic figure, the Black Knight, who arrived to aid him, Ivanhoe defeated his challengers and won once again. After his victory, the Black Knight disappeared. Rowena presented a crown to the Black Knight, who was now forced to lift his visor and reveal his face. He was known to everyone as Ivanhoe, the son of Cedric. With a heavy heart, he fainted at Rowena's feet.

0.text: As Fouquet accompanies D'Artagnan to see the King, a man shoves a piece of paper in his hand. While D'Artagnan is talking with the King, Fouquet reads the letter. In Gourville's handwriting, the letter informs Fouquet that a white horse is ready to bear him to safety. The Fouquet destroys the note. Fouquet goes in to see the King. The King asks after his health. Fouquet makes one last attempt to clear his name and defend himself. A little while into their conversation, it is clear Fouquet needs to go to bed. The King summons D'Artagnan to escort the man. Fouquet refuses, saying that a simple footman would do. Once Fouquet leaves, the King orders that D'Artagnan follow him. He asks D'Artagnan to arrest Fouquet, then orders a bunch of draconian measures like a special carriage to prevent notes being thrown out the window. D'Artagnan admits to the King that he tried to save Fouquet, but says that now he will execute his orders. D'Artagnan leaves the King. As he leaves, he sees a very cheerful Gourville heading to Fouquet's lodgings.

2.text: When Fouquet accompanied D'Artagnan to meet the King, a man pushed a piece of paper into his hand. As D'Artagnan was conversing with the King, Fouquet read the letter. The letter, written in Gourville's hand, informed Fouquet that a white horse was ready to take him to a safe place. Fouquet destroyed the letter. Fouquet then entered to meet the King. The King inquired about his health. Fouquet attempted once more to clarify his honor and self-defense. Shortly after the conversation began, it was clear that Fouquet needed to sleep. The King summoned D'Artagnan to follow the man. Fouquet refused, saying that a simple servant would suffice. As Fouquet departed, the King ordered D'Artagnan to follow him. He instructed D'Artagnan to apprehend Fouquet, then issued some stern measures, such as a special carriage to prevent the letter from being thrown out the window. D'Artagnan confessed to the King that he had attempted to save Fouquet, but now he would carry out his orders. D'Artagnan left the King. As he departed, he saw a very cheerful Gourville approaching Fouquet's house.

Fouquet once again attempted to clarify his honor and protect his interests. From the beginning of the conversation, it was clear that Fouquet needed a short period of rest. The king summoned D'Artagnan to follow him. Fouquet refused, saying that a regular servant would be enough. As Fouquet left, the king ordered D'Artagnan to follow him. He requested D'Artagnan to apprehend Fouquet and then implement strict measures, such as a private carriage, to prevent letters from being thrown out the window. D'Artagnan confessed to the king that he had tried to save Fouquet, but now he would carry out the king's orders. D'Artagnan left the king. As he walked, he saw Gourville, who was very excited, visiting Fouquet's house.

When D'Artagnan was searching for Fouquet, he encountered the king, who had sent a letter to D'Artagnan.  While D'Artagnan was conversing with the king, Fouquet read a letter from Gourville.  The letter from Gourville informed Fouquet that a white horse was ready to take him to a safe place.  Fouquet then tore the letter into small pieces.  He later met the king again.  The king inquired about Fouquet's health.  Fouquet once again attempted to clarify his identity and protect his interests.  From the start of the conversation, it was clear that Fouquet needed a short period of rest.  The king summoned D'Artagnan to accompany him.  Fouquet refused, saying that regular staff would be sufficient.

When Fouquet left, the king ordered D'Artagnan to follow him.  The king entrusted D'Artagnan with the task of arresting Fouquet and implementing strict measures, such as personal protection, to prevent the letter from being thrown out the window.  D'Artagnan confessed to the king that he had attempted to save Fouquet, but now he would follow the king's orders.  D'Artagnan left the king.  When he arrived, he saw Gourville, who was very enthusiastic, approaching Fouquet's house.

D'Artagnan arrived at Fouquet's house.  When he arrived, he saw Fouquet lying on the bed, looking very tired.  D'Artagnan tried to keep Fouquet from realizing that he had been caught.  He then left Fouquet's house and returned to the king.  When he arrived, he saw the king very worried.  The king inquired about Fouquet, and D'Artagnan confessed that he had failed to arrest Fouquet.  The king asked why D'Artagnan had failed to arrest Fouquet.  D'Artagnan explained that Fouquet had been taken away by a friend, and he was unable to follow.

The king inquired about the friend, and D'Artagnan said it was Gourville.  The king asked why Gourville had helped Fouquet, and D'Artagnan explained that Gourville was a close friend of Fouquet.  The king inquired about Fouquet's plan, and D'Artagnan confessed that he did not know.  The king inquired about Gourville's plan, and D'Artagnan said he did not know.  The king inquired about D'Artagnan's plan, and D'Artagnan said he would investigate and report back to the king.

0.text: Determined to fight off her depression, Eustacia decides to go to a 'gipsying,' or dance, in East Egdon. Envious of the young people dancing, and later, surprised by Wildeve's presence there, she consents to dance with her former lover and enjoys it more than she can understand. Allowing Wildeve to walk part way home with her, she encounters Clym and Venn, though Wildeve leaves her before Clym can see him. Sure he has seen Wildeve with Eustacia, Venn hurries to the inn and learns from questioning Thomasin that it was her husband. Thereupon, Venn keeps watch on Clym's house and on several occasions frustrates Wildeve's loitering outside the house and trying to communicate with Eustacia. Venn also calls on Mrs. Yeobright, urging her to establish relations with both Clym and Thomasin for the good of all. She decides to forgive Clym and call on him. At the same time, Clym tells Eustacia he must do something to improve relations with his mother.

0.text: Chapter 33 jumps backwards in time a bit. Cathy and Hareton grow closer, though the sight of it annoys both Joseph and Heathcliff. Together they plant a garden, but dig up Joseph's plants to do it. When Heathcliff scolds them for touching the property, Cathy stands up for herself, saying, 'You shouldn't grudge a few yards of earth for me to ornament when you have taken all my land!' . She also accuses Heathcliff of robbing Hareton of his land and money. Heathcliff storms out. He returns later to find Hareton and Cathy reading together. Unexpectedly, Heathcliff does not fly into a rage. Instead he confesses to Nelly that he has lost interest in revenge. 'hen everything is ready, and in my power, I find the will to lift a slate off either roof has vanished!' . Heathcliff continues to be struck by Hareton's resemblance to Catherine. But then, everything reminds him of Catherine. He tells Nelly that he is a changed man. He no longer has the will to live but yearns for only one thing.

0.text: Ellen, distressed by Edgar's refusal to console Isabella, went to visit her at Wuthering Heights. She told Isabella and Heathcliff that Catherine would 'never be what she was' and that Heathcliff should not bother her anymore. Heathcliff asserted that he would not leave her to Edgar's lukewarm care, and that she loved him much more than her husband. He said that if he had been in Edgar's place he would never have interfered with Catherine's friendships, although he would kill the friend the moment Catherine no longer cared about him. Ellen urged Heathcliff to treat Isabella better, and he expressed his scorn and hatred for his wife. He said Isabella knew what he was when she married him: she had seen him hanging her pet dog. Isabella told Ellen that she hated Heathcliff, and he ordered her upstairs so he could talk to Ellen. Alone with her, he told her that if she did not arrange an interview for him with Catherine, he would force his way in armed, and she agreed to give Catherine a letter from him

2.text: When Edgar refused to calm Isabella down, Ellen felt anxious and decided to visit her at Wuthering Heights. She told Isabella and Heathcliff that 'Catherine had never truly lived' and would never return, and that Heathcliff should not bother her anymore. Heathcliff was resolute that he could not leave her in Edgar's loose care, and that she loved him more than her husband. He said that if he were in Edgar's position, he would never intervene in Catherine's relationship, although he would kill Catherine's friends immediately if Catherine no longer cared about him. Ellen advised Heathcliff to treat Isabella better, and he showed disdain and hatred for his wife. He told Isabella that she knew who he was when she married him: she had seen him hang her beloved cat. Isabella told Ellen that she hated Heathcliff, and he asked her to go upstairs so he could speak with Ellen alone. Alone with her, he told her that if she did not arrange a meeting between him and Catherine, he would break in with a weapon, and she agreed to let Catherine write a letter to him.

0.text: The group spends the night around a fire in the desolate ruins of the fort. They eat bear meat for dinner. Looking out at the lake, Heyward hears noises. Uncas explain that wolves are prowling nearby. Hawkeye is pondering the meaning of paradise when he hears another sound. Uncas goes to investigate, and the group hears a rifle shot. Chingachgook follows his son, and those left behind hear a splash of water and another rifle shot. Chingachgook and Uncas return calmly. When Heyward asks what happened, Uncas shows him the scalp of an Oneida. After discussing the plan for the next day, the group falls asleep
